wikipedia_page.main: Dame Athene Margaret Donald  (née Griffith; born 15 May 1953) is a British physicist. She is Professor of Experimental Physics at the University of Cambridge, and Master of Churchill College, Cambridge.

response: *  1953   – Athene Donald, English physicist and academic

link_mentions.page: Colleges of the University of Cambridge

response: # Athene Donald FRS, Professor of Experimental Physics, Master of Churchill College, Cambridge
* Dame Athene Donald, Deputy Head of the Cavendish Laboratory
*2015 Dame Athene Donald FRS, physicist and Master since 2014 of Churchill College, Cambridge

* University research fellowships (URFs) Royal Society University Research Fellowships are for outstanding scientists in the UK who are in the early stages of their research career and have the potential to become leaders in their field. Previous holders of URFs have been elected FRS at a later date including Richard Borcherds (1994), Jean Beggs (1998), Frances Ashcroft (1999), Athene Donald (1999) and John Pethica (1999). More recent awardees include Terri Attwood, Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, Brian Cox, Sarah Bridle, Shahn Majid, Tanya Monro, Beth Shapiro, David J. Wales and Katherine Willis.
* May 15 – Athene Donald (née Griffith), English experimental physicist.
* Athene Donald (born 1953), Professor of Experimental Physics at the University of Cambridge
*2006 Athene Donald, The mesoscopic world - from plastic bags to brain disease - structural similarities in physics

link_mentions.page: List of current heads of University of Cambridge colleges

response: Churchill celebrated its diamond jubilee in 2017. A new Computing and Business Studies block, named the Alan Turing Building, was built and completed in 2017. Funding was also received in 2017 to build a new Science and Technology block to replace the original 1956 building known as "Tudor Block." The new building was named the Dame Athene Donald Building following a student competition.

response: *2010 Athene Donald, "For her many highly original studies of the structures and behaviour of polymers both synthetic and natural"
